study_identification.title: Developmental trajectories of neuroanatomical alterations associated with the 16p11.2 Copy Number Variations

study_characteristics.study_objective: To characterize age-related effects of 16p11.2 copy number variants by analyzing a group with a broad age range including younger individuals. A large normative developmental dataset was used to accurately adjust for effects of age.

reference_cohort_and_imaging.dataset_name: NIH MRI study of normal brain development (NIHPD)
reference_cohort_and_imaging.hc_age: mean 11.0 at first scan; range 4.5 to 18.5 years
reference_cohort_and_imaging.quality_checking_detail: Only subjects that passed quality control were included. For the 16p11.2 cohort, a thorough visual quality control check was performed.
reference_cohort_and_imaging.site_effect_handling_detail: Mixed-effect models to account for within-participant correlation. A fixed effect for individual scanner was tested but not significant. A linear model was used to correct for bias and slope differences between the normative and case-control datasets.

normative_modeling.model_origin_detail: The normative model (Aubert-Broche et al., 2011) used data from 339 children (179 females and 160 males), scanned longitudinally at 2 or 3 time points, with approximately 24 months between scans and mean age at first scan of 11.0 years, for a total of 874 scans.
normative_modeling.response_variable: Global brain volume; voxel-wise log-transformed Jacobian determinants
normative_modeling.predictor_effects: Age: fixed (linear and quadratic) and random (linear) effects. Sex: fixed effect.

nm_vldtn_handle_ns.Reason: The study explicitly models age and sex effects. It also tested for scanner effects, but they were not significant. A linear correction was applied to account for differences in scanning protocols between the normative and the case-control datasets.
nm_vldtn_handle_ns.Supporting_Text: During model selection, a fixed effect for individual scanner was tested but found to be not significant and the model was associated with a higher Bayesian Information Criterion (BIC). After normalization of the 16p11.2 controls, we observed that certain regions required small additional corrections attributed to differences in scanning parameters between the NIHPD and the 16p11.2 data (e.g. 1.5 T vs 3T scans). We estimated a linear model that included Age and Intercept (i.e. bias and slope) for the Z-scored segmented volumes and the voxel-wise log-transformed Jacobian determinants of the 16p11.2 control data.

nm_vldtn_same_domain_nonindep.Reason: The paper does not describe any validation on a non-independent subset of the training data.

nm_vldtn_same_domain_indep.Reason: The paper does not describe any validation on an independent subset of the training data.

nm_vldtn_diff_domain.Reason: The normative model, trained on the NIHPD dataset, is applied to the 16p11.2 dataset, which is from a different domain (different scanners, field strengths, and populations). The authors perform a linear correction to adjust for the domain shift.
nm_vldtn_diff_domain.Supporting_Text: After normalization of the 16p11.2 controls, we observed that certain regions required small additional corrections attributed to differences in scanning parameters between the NIHPD and the 16p11.2 data (e.g. 1.5 T vs 3T scans).

clinical_application_and_analysis.clinical_dataset: 16p11.2 CNVs cohort (European -EU 16p11.2 consortium and the Simons VIP -SVIP study in North America)
clinical_application_and_analysis.clinical_groups_sex: DEL: M 29, F 27; DUP: M 13, F 6; CTRL: M 67, F 38
clinical_application_and_analysis.association_analysis: Linear model with genetic status as a covariate. Interaction terms age*sex and age*group were tested. Bonferroni correction for global volumes and FDR for voxel-wise analysis.
clinical_application_and_analysis.key_findings_brief: 16p11.2 CNV carriers have brain alterations present already at 4.5 years, with comparable effect size from 5 to 20 years of age.
clinical_application_and_analysis.key_findings_detailed: Deletion carriers have higher total brain, gray and white matter volumes, while duplication carriers show the opposite effect. Voxel-based analyses show an inverse gene dosage effect in bilateral calcarine cortex, insula, left transverse temporal gyrus, planum temporale and parietal operculum. These differences are stable across the studied age range.
clinical_application_and_analysis.key_limitations: Technical differences in acquisition (1.5T vs 3T, multi-center). Power to observe age-related differences was constrained by sample size. Results may not generalize to carriers with extreme obesity or severe ASD.
clinical_application_and_analysis.application_notes: The study demonstrates a method to normalize for non-linear age effects using a large normative dataset, even when acquired with different scanners. This allows for the study of rare genetic conditions across a wide age range.

general_notes: The study uses a pre-existing normative model and applies it to a new dataset. A key contribution is the method to correct for scanner differences between the normative and the application dataset.
